meaning: To come into sight; to become visible or noticeable. It can also mean to seem or give the impression of being something.
etymology: The word 'appear' originates from the Latin word 'apparere', which means 'to come in sight, make an appearance'. It is derived from 'ad-' (to) + 'parere' (to come forth, be visible).
sentence: The sun will appear at dawn.
She did not appear to be upset by the news.
Famous quote: 'Things are not always what they appear to be.' - Phaedrus
short_stories: In a small village, a mysterious figure would appear every full moon, leaving behind a single red rose. No one knew who it was or why they came, but it became a cherished mystery.
A young boy wished every night to see a shooting star. One night, a bright light appeared in the sky, and he made a wish that changed his life forever.
poetry: Excerpt from 'The Raven' by Edgar Allan Poe: 'Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing, Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before; But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token, And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, 'Lenore?' This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, 'Lenore!'— Merely this and nothing more.'
Excerpt from 'The Road Not Taken' by Robert Frost: 'Two roads diverged in a wood, and I— I took the one less traveled by, And that has made all the difference.'
